title: Patriots vs. Raiders live updates: Will New England start Mike Vrabel era with a win?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots begin the 2025 season against the Las Vegas Raiders at Gillette Stadium under new head coach Mike Vrabel.
Patriots' rookie Will Campbell will play despite an ankle injury, facing a challenge against Raiders' Maxx Crosby.
Kicker Andy Borregales showcased his skills with a successful 50-yard field goal in pre-game warmups at a rainy stadium.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys' Ken Casey criticized former President Trump during their performance at the Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Marine veteran and oyster farmer, seeking to challenge GOP Sen. Susan Collins in Maine.
Platner is described as a millennial eager to oppose Trumpism and willing to critique the Democratic establishment.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu's program converted five floors of offices into 15 apartments at 281 Franklin St. in Boston.
The program, launched in October 2023, received an additional $15 million funding and aims to create over 800 new units.
Critics urge broader strategies due to high office vacancy rates; Wu's opponent calls for public-private partnerships.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Disciplinary cases at Harvard tripled in the 2023-2024 academic year due to pro-Palestine protests, reports The Harvard Crimson.
More than half of 90 disciplined students violated protest policies, participating in unsanctioned protests like the April 2024 encampment.
Harvard's Administrative Board placed 58 students on probation, monitoring them for further violations after reducing some suspensions.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: Day 1 of the Seisiún Irish music festival took place amidst rain at Suffolk Downs in Boston.
Performers included Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, The Rumjacks, The Scratch, and Holy Locust.
The festival continued despite weather disruptions, with attendees returning post-rain delay.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective at Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Maine, spans 60 years and includes 149 original artworks.
Steadman recounts a 1970 incident with Hunter S. Thompson involving drugs and a near-vandalism of yachts in Newport, Rhode Island.
The exhibit includes collaborations with Hunter S. Thompson and features Steadman's work on 'Alice in Wonderland' and 'Treasure Island.'

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill may cause 40,000 Boston-area adults to lose SNAP benefits, affecting 7% of recipients.
Report states that 9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts risk losing SNAP eligibility under new federal rules.
Massachusetts faces increased SNAP costs, with state covering 75% of administrative costs, totaling $175 million by 2025.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Revolution's playoff hopes dimmed after a 3-2 defeat to Chicago Fire, falling to an 8-14-7 record.
Missing key players, Revolution struggled defensively, conceding early goals by Jonathan Bamba and Philip Zinckernagel.
With five games left, the Revolution are 11 points behind playoff qualification, needing unlikely results to advance.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election is set for Sept. 9, featuring races for mayor and multiple City Council seats.
Ten candidates compete for four at-large City Council positions, with eight advancing to the general election.
Current Mayor Michelle Wu faces challengers including philanthropist Josh Kraft in the mayoral race.

title: Maren Morris brings her divorce album to Leader Bank Pavilion
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Maren Morris performed at Leader Bank Pavilion, featuring her full 'Dreamsicle' album, focusing on current themes over past hits.
Morris shared personal experiences from her divorce through her music, supported by audience participation on anthems like 'Lemonade'.
The concert was affected by sound issues, but showcased Morris's strength in 80s-inspired pop production and vocal delivery.
